bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, December 9, 1899
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General
Third Assistant U.S. Secretary of State

div1.p: No. 41, Consular Series. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, Dec. 9, 1899.

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D FEB 5 '00 DEPT OF STATE

div1.p: Owen L. W. Smith To Hon. Thos., W. Cridler, Third Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.
Subject. Reply to your No. 23, of Sept. 2, 1899; relative to vacating the present premises occupied for United States Legation Monrovia, Liberia.
No. 41. Consular Series. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia; Dec., 9, 1899.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt Oct., 13, of your No. 23, of Sept., 2, 1899; advising that I vacate the present premises, used as United States Legation Monrovia; provided the administrator Hon., R. H. Jackson, will not sink a well on the said premises.
In reply, I beg to say, I have just, yesterday, succeeded in having an interview with Senator Jackson, relative to the

the advice of the Department. He says it is not practiceable to sink a well, on the said premisees, owing to the rocky foundation, and the want of proper machinery for drilling &c. He says he prefers that the United States, shall have the use of the said premises, but if it will not retain the use, thereof, without the sinking of a well, it will have to vacate.

Owing to the scarcity of respectable and well situated property that can be rented, I think it best not to hurry out. It is possibly probable that I can equally as good quarters, with a well on the premsises, for about the same, rent, though not as desireably sitated, in about a twelve months
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, M. R. and C. General.
